question.title: How to show cursor in TextField with selected text in JavaFX?
question.body:
I have a text field where text should be selected. But when all text is selected the cursor is not visible. This is my code:

public class NewMain1 extends Application {

    @Override
    public void start(Stage primaryStage) {
        var badTextField = new TextField("Some text");
        VBox root = new VBox(badTextField);
        root.setPadding(new Insets(15));
        Scene scene = new Scene(root, 300, 100);
        primaryStage.setScene(scene);
        primaryStage.show();
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        launch(args);
    }
}

And this is output:

As you see the cursor in not visible when text is selected. At the same time in Swing cursor is visible:

Could anyone say how to show cursor with selected text in TextField if it is possible?

question_comments.body: The behavior isn't different; the appearance is different. There are places in JavaFX where controls are coded to mimic their native counterparts so as to be intuitive for users of the specific platform. The code I linked above which is windows-specific references a bug (JDK-8111037), though I am unable to find a reference to that bug currently.
@James_D But shouldnâ€™t the behavior be the same across all operating systems?

This is by design. The logic coded into the skin is to make the caret visible when the control is focused and the selection is empty, except on windows, when the selection is not taken into account. As far as I can tell, the only way to change this would be with a custom skin.
Which version of JavaFX are you working with? With FX21 I am able to see the cursor blinking when the text is selected. imgur.com/a/v600VaD
The JavaFX behavior seems more standard and intuitive than the Swing behavior IMO. If you want the Swing behavior, you could use a SwingNode, though I would recommend against that.

Do any other applications show the cursor when there is a selection?  Usually, an application should conform to the normal behavior of the desktop, so users are familiar with it and comfortable with it.
